Get Into Phyco¶

What is Phyco?¶

Phyco is a developing physics engine implemented mainly in Python 3. For now, it supports to 3-D multi-mass-point simulation in various types of force field. Collision detection is finished and tested in some conditions, though supports only 2-body collision. Further developing is in progress.

Though Phyco are to be a physics engine, it supports not only physics simulations, that is, building it calls not only for physics formulas and programming skills. Phyco also integrated a fairly adequate math processor, with capability to (more info in Math manipulations in Phyco):

  • Process symbolic math expressions (expr class);
  • Do vector manipulations (vector class);
  • Do some operation on matrices such as compute determinants (matrix class);
  • Do differentiation to elementary functions (diff class).

Alongside with math, Phyco do string match by Aho-Corasick Algorithm, in both symbolic expression handling and aliasing feature.

Something to know about Phyco~¶

Phyco is originally written in Python 3.4 and diverted to 3.5, and is reforming to integrate C++ extensions for better performance.

Written in Python, Phyco generally inherits Python PEP 20 and some other spirits and mottos of Python, and is highly Object-Oriented. Besides, Phyco takes flexiblity as the first. Using Phyco do not require knowledge in programming (Ugh, little maybe), but there’s a few conventions or terms used in this document that would be confusing if without Python background.

  • Unlike much programming language, Phyco allows you aliasing which might be opposite to

    There should be one– and preferably only one –obvious way to do it.

  • Anything you will see in Phyco can be generally called as Object without specifying its type.

  • class as a qualifier can be thought as a category of objects or a type of objects.

  • All self in documents refers the object itself.

  • There’re a few syntaxes (called iterable) require to use brackets of any type {, [, (, which doesn’t matter, but be cautious to use {

Caution

In Python, {} denotes a dictionary (though you don’t have to really know it), which is not a typical sequence type. However, if there’s content in brackets like {'a'} denotes a set.

Phyco Structure¶

The top level of Phyco (User Interface, UI) is command line (shell), which you use to send command. A valid Phyco command can have only one verb which must be at the beginning. Knowing this is enough to use Phyco, but you’re welcomed to be curious about what will be done inside Phyco. (You’re recommended to try using Phyco before seeing the following.)

Every input of yours are firstly translated to python code. (This is not so good though.) Any Object you created are stored in a dict. You may have tried to either set a property of an object or create an object with a property embeded in initially. This is achieved by setting attributes of your object.

As you start a sim, a lot of things are done, and this might be the core of Phyco. pass!

Types in Phyco¶

Types is something fundamental in Phyco. Everything encountered should have a type. It seems awkward for new comers that a few words like type, class or object are introduced. But you just feel free to use it just as everyday you do. In Phyco, here’s a few types of modules, namely:

  • Mechanics Types: object, constraint
  • Sim Types: simulation, event
  • LinAlg Types: vector, matrix, field
  • Geom Types: Under Construction
  • ... (more in Phyco but you won’t meet them so soon)

But it’s never necessary for you to remember which specific type belongs to which module, it’s auto completed in Phyco anytime once needed. You can also find specific help doc to know them better.
